entities.name: parvati
entities.description: Parvati is mentioned as one of the students who puts her hand over her mouth in horror when Professor Trelawney says she saw Death during her crystal gazing. ("Parvati and Lavender both put their hands over their mouths, looking horrified.")

entities.name: lavender
entities.description: Lavender is mentioned as one of the students who puts her hand over her mouth in horror when Professor Trelawney says she saw Death during her crystal gazing. ("Parvati and Lavender both put their hands over their mouths, looking horrified.")

entities.name: professor trelawney
entities.description: Professor Trelawney is mentioned as the one who claims to have seen Death during her crystal gazing. ("Yes," said Professor Trelawney, nodding impressively, "it comes, ever closer, it circles overhead like a vulture, ever lower . . . ever lower over the castle.")

entities.name: death
entities.description: Death is mentioned as something that Professor Trelawney claims to have seen during her crystal gazing. ("Death, my dears." "Yes," said Professor Trelawney, nodding impressively, "it comes, ever closer, it circles overhead like a vulture, ever lower . . . ever lower over the castle.")

entities.name: harry
entities.description: Harry is mentioned as one of the students who is stared at by Professor Trelawney. ("As I sat here, absorbed in my needlework, th e urge to consult the orb overpowered me. I arose, I settled myself before it, and I gazed into its crystalline depths . . . and what do  you think I saw gazing back at me?" "Death, my dears." Professor Trelawney stared pointedly at Harry, who yawned very widely and obviously.)

entities.name: ron
entities.description: Ron is mentioned as one of the students who makes a comment about what he thinks Professor Trelawney saw during her crystal gazing. ("An ugly old bat in outsize specs?" Ron muttered under his breath.)

relationships.description: Professor Trelawney claims to have seen Death during her crystal gazing. ("Yes," said Professor Trelawney, nodding impressively, "it comes, ever closer, it circles overhead like a vulture, ever lower . . . ever lower over the castle.")
